title: What are the trends in publicly funded adult social care staff numbers?
analysis_commentary:
Here we look at data on staff (directly and indirectly) employed by adult social services departments in England only. The data does not include information on privately funded social care, or children's social services. For more information on this data please see 'about this data' below.

For the smallest group, professional staff (which include social workers, occupational therapists, registered nurses and allied health professionals), the percentage change increases by 3% from 2011 to 2013; this is the only group who experience an increase. Their numbers remained fairly consistent however (just under 20,000) over the three years. The other three, larger groups have decreased: managers, supervisors by 13%; other staff (which includes roles not directly involved in providing care and support, such as HR and IT) by 14%; and direct care (which includes all roles which provide care or support directly, such as care workers and support workers) decreased by 18% in two years. The total number of whole time equivalents for all staff groups has also decreased by around 14,000 from 2011 to 2013.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Social Services: Staff of Social Services Departments
